title.narrative: IN Uttarakhand Water Supply and Sanitation Project

description.narrative: To improve the effectiveness of Rural Water Supply and Sanitation (RWSS) services through decentralization and increased role of Panchayati Raj Institutions and local communities in the state of Uttarakhand and restore services of damaged schemes in disaster affected areas.

participating-org.narrative: DEA, Ministry of Finance, Goverment of India

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Project Agreement Schedule Section II. 3 | Description :(a) A system is established to ensure that funds for allproject-financed MVS to be carried out under the project and costing upto Rs. 20 lakhs, flow through the relevant DWSM | Due Date:31-Dec-2006

Finance Agreement :Project Agreement Schedule Section II. 3 | Description :(b) Project Monitoring and evaluation system isestablished, fully operational and thereafter maintained. | Due Date :31-Dec-2006

Finance Agreement :Project Agreement Schedule Section II. 4 | Description :(a) 75% of Batch One investment schemes have entered theimplementation cycle of activities in accordance with the provisions set forth in the Operations Manual | Due Date :30-Sep-2007

Finance Agreement :Project Agreement Schedule Section II. 4 | Description :(b) All of the Batch Two investment schemes have beenidentified in accordance with the provisions set forth in the Operations Manual | Due Date :30-Sep-2007
Finance Agreement :Project Agreement Schedule Section II. 5 | Description :(a) The Staff of UJN & UJS engaged in rural water supplyschemes report to the relevant PRI | Due Date :31-Mar-2009

Finance Agreement :Project Agreement Schedule Section II. 5 | Description :An assessment carried out on progress of fund flow forall project-financed MVS carried out under project and such assessment setforth appropriate recommendations | Due Date :31-Mar-2009

title.narrative: People provided with access to "improved sanitation facilities” under the proj.
People provided with access to “improved sanitation facilities”- rural
Component B: Percentage of habitations under: (a) Fully covered (FC) category(b) Partially covered (PC) category(c) Not Covered (NC) category
Number of people in rural areas provided with access to Improved Water Sources under the project
New piped household water connections that are resulting from the project intervention
People trained to improve hygiene behavior/sanitation practices - female
Number of other water service providers that the project is supporting
Improved community water points constructed or rehabilitated under the project
People trained to improve hygiene behavior/sanitation practices under the proj
Piped household water connections that are benefiting from rehabilitation works undertaken by the project
Improved latrines constructed under the project
Component B: Percentage of GPs and habitations that are declared open-defecation free.
Number of water utilities that the project is supporting
Component C: Expenditures of supply driven schemes as a percentage of total sector expenditures.
Increase in the number of people having access to improved water supply delivery
Component B: Number of SVSs constructed and operating according to SWAp principles
Increase in the number of households adopting improved hygiene and sanitation practices in the state
Improved financial performance of the water supply schemes: (a) SVS-100% for O&M; (b) MVS - in accordance with GoUA's cost-sharing policy for RWSS sector

actual.value: Strong evidence of improved financial performance of the water supply schemes. SVS - O&M fully devolved to Gram Panchayats withmore than 80% O&M cost recovery. MVS - tariffs as per State (UJS) cost sharing policy fully implemented..

title.narrative: High satisfaction level in participating communities

baseline.value: No information: Implementation phase yet to begin

actual.value: High satisfaction levels. 98% users satisfied with quantity and quality of water received.

title.narrative: Institutional effectiveness evident in each sector (balanced scorecard will be developed to assess effectiveness via reports from independent technical and social audit teams).

actual.value: Strong evidence of institutional effectiveness and decentralization.

title.narrative: Component A: SWAp principles demonstrated to work successfully and could be replicated as a tested approach to RWSS service delivery in India

actual.value: Strong evidence emerging. SVS and MVS provide models for replication. The models have influenced GOI guidelines, including use ofthese models for the recent multi- state LIS Project.

title.narrative: Component A: The envisaged decentralized institutional framework (for UJN, UJS, SWSM, DWSM and PRIs) is achieved and operational

baseline.value: PRIs, UJN and UJS are the main service providers

target.value: Sector institutional framework operational for all schemes in the sector

actual.value: Fully operational. Sector institutional framework operational for all schemes in the sector.

title.narrative: Component B: Number of MVS schemes constructed and operating according to SWAp principles

baseline.value: Preparation and implementation yet to begin

title.narrative: Component A: SWSM and DWSM are established and their cells are fully staffed and functional

baseline.value: SWSM and DWSM are established and their cells are partially staffed

title.narrative: Component C: Comprehensive M&E system is established and functional for the sector.

actual.value: M&E system established and fully functional.

title.narrative: Component A: Sector Information system, water quality monitoring program, and source measurement programs are implemented.
Component D (AF): Number of soak pits reconstructed and restored
Component D (AF): Number of IHHL Reconstructed and Restored
Component D (AF): Length of drains reconstructed and restored
Component D (AF):Number of Schemes reconstructed and restored
